results.title: Antigone by Sophocles: a discussion
results.creator_credit: David Zweck and Country Education Project
results.brief_description: Dennis Pryor of Melbourne Univeristy and Jenny Webb discuss Sophocles’ play in detail. Characters, themes and backgrounds are explored and illustrated with readings from the play.

results.title: Anthropology and the future
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, Ira R. Abrams, Coast Community College District and Holt, Rinehart and Winston
results.brief_description:
Episode number 26 of Series “Faces of culture”.
In this last program of the series, anthropologist and producer of the series Ira R. Abrams, leads a discussion with two other anthropologists, Napoleon A. Chagnon and Laura Nader on the future of anthropology. Is the subject matter of anthropology disappearing or simply changing? What are the ethical consequences of the anthropologist’s work? Where does the future of anthropology lie? The ideas discussed are various and fascinating, and in the light of recent developments in world power structures, and in the Amazonian jungles, timely and thought provoking too.

results.title: Antarctica (Episode 3)
results.brief_description: Looks at the heroic early exploration of the continent and the ensuing exploitation if its wildlife, the flora and fauna, and the scientific studies beng carried out in Antarctica today. The possibility of future utilization of Antarctica’s mineral wealth is discusssed.

results.title: Antarctica
results.creator_credit: Bastian Wimmer, Clayton J. Edwards and Image Associates
results.brief_description: Examines some of the significant research projects being carried out in Antartica under the auspices of the National Science Foundation. Shows how these projects relate to worldwide concerns and emphasizes the cooperation of American scientists with those from other countries.

results.title: Antarctic man. No. 2. This is not a place for humans
results.creator_credit: David Parer and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description: This is the second part of a two-part documentary recording the International Biomedical Expedition to the Antarctic. The purpose of the expedition was to measure the effects of the Antarctic environment on both the human body and mind, including the extreme cold climate, isolation and separation from family and home. Shows the physiological and psychological pressures and physical limits the Expedition set for themselves. Some coped, some didn’t - but the ordeal had a lasting effect on all of them. Narrated by W. Francis Bell.
results.title_for_label: Antarctic man. No. 2. This is not a place for humans

results.title: Antamosi
results.creator_credit: Ana Kokkinos and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: Memories, betrayals and secrets emerge from the past when Katina’s mother comes from Greece to visit the family. As the truth about the family’s war-time involvement is revealed, the bitter embrace between mother and daughter is observed by Katina’s own daughter Sophia who must play her own role in this moving drama of estrangement.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ana Kokkinos and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School

results.title: Ant world
results.brief_description: Shows the life style of the common ant. Tells how the class structure of certain ant colonies constitutes a society based on a division of labour. Records home-building and food-gathering techniques and documents the exchange of a salivery substance between a smaller male and larger female ant. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
results.description: Shows the life style of the common ant. Tells how the class structure of certain ant colonies constitutes a society based on a division of labour. results.title: Anoop and the elephant
results.creator_credit: David Eady, Hugh Stewart, Anvil Films and Children's Film Foundation
results.brief_description: Engaging and highly entertaining children’s adventure story set in the world of the circus. Anoop, an Indian boy, and his friends attempt to rescue a performing elephant (Riley) from a life in the circus. Cast includes Jimmy Edwards.

results.title: Annie's Coming Out (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Gil Brealey, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A warm, moving film experience and a triumph of the human spirit. “Annie’s Coming Out” is based on the true story of Annie McDonald. Jessica Hathaway (Angela Punch McGregor) works at a hospital for handicapped children, and among her charges is Annie, a victim of cerebral palsy. Discovering Annie’s considerable intelligence, Jessica endeavours to prove this and must take her case to court in a battle against the establishment.
